Statement: Given the axioms for multiplication: If $x \neq 0$ and $x y=x z$ then $y=z$.
Given the axioms for multiplication: If $x \neq 0$ and $x y=x$ then $y=1$.
Given the axioms for multiplication: If $x \neq 0$ and $x y=1$ then $y=1 / x$.
Given the axioms for multiplication: If $x \neq 0$ then $1 /(1 / x)=x$.
The axioms for addition imply: If $x+y=x+z$ then $y=z$.
Proof:
If $x+y=x+z$, the axioms (A) give

$$
\begin{aligned}
y=0+y & =(-x+x)+y=-x+(x+y) \\
& =-x+(x+z)=(-x+x)+z=0+z=z
\end{aligned}
$$

This proves $(a)$.

Statement: The axioms for addition imply: If $x+y=x$ then $y=0$.
The axioms for addition imply: If $x+y=0$ then $y=-x$.
In every ordered field: If $x>0$ then $-x<0$, and vice versa.
Proof: If $x>0$ then $0=-x+x>-x+0$, so that $-x<0$. If $x<0$ then $0=-x+x<-x+0$, so that $-x>0$. This proves $(a)$.

Statement: In every ordered field: If $x>0$ and $y<z$ then $x y<x z$.
Proof:
Since $z>y$, we have $z-y>y-y=0$, hence $x(z-y)>0$, and therefore

$$
x z=x(z-y)+x y>0+x y=x y .
$$

Statement: In every ordered field: If $x<0$ and $y<z$ then $x y>x z$.
Proof:
By $(a),(b)$, and Proposition 1.16(c),

$$
-[x(z-y)]=(-x)(z-y)>0
$$

so that $x(z-y)<0$, hence $x z<x y$.

Statement: In every ordered field: If $x \neq 0$ then $x^{2}>0$. In particular, $1>0$.
Proof: If $x>0$, part (ii) of Definition 1.17 gives $x^{2}>0$. If $x<0$, then $-x>0$, hence $(-x)^{2}>0$. But $x^{2}=(-x)^{2}$, by Proposition $1.16(d)$. Since $1=1^{2}, 1>0$.

Statement: In every ordered field: If $0<x<y$ then $0<1 / y<1 / x$.
Proof: If $y>0$ and $v \leq 0$, then $y v \leq 0$. But $y \cdot(1 / y)=1>0$. Hence $1 / y>0$. Likewise, $1 / x>0$. If we multiply both sides of the inequality $x<y$ by the positive quantity $(1 / x)(1 / y)$, we obtain $1 / y<1 / x$.

Statement: The field axioms imply the following statement for any $x \in F$: $0 x=0$.
Proof: $0 x+0 x=(0+0) x=0 x$. Hence $1.14(b)$ implies that $0 x=0$, and (a) holds.

Statement: The field axioms imply the following statement for any $x, y \in F$: $(-x) y=-(x y)=x(-y)$.
Proof:

$$

If $P$ is a projection in $X$, then every $\mathbf{x} \in X$ has a unique representation of the form

$$
\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{1}+\mathbf{x}_{2}
$$

where $\mathbf{x}_{1} \in \mathscr{R}(P), \mathbf{x}_{2} \in \mathscr{N}(P)$
Proof: To obtain the representation, put $\mathbf{x}_{1}=P \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}_{2}=\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{1}$. Then $P \mathrm{x}_{2}=P \mathrm{x}-P \mathbf{x}_{1}=P \mathrm{x}-P^{2} \mathbf{x}=0$. As regards the uniqueness, apply $P$ to the equation $\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{1}+\mathbf{x}_{2}$. Since $\mathbf{x}_{1} \in \mathscr{R}(P), P \mathbf{x}_{1}=\mathbf{x}_{1} ;$ since $P \mathbf{x}_{2}=0$, it follows that $\mathbf{x}_{1}=P \mathbf{x}$.

Statement: If $X$ is a finite-dimensional vector space and if $X_{1}$ is a vector space in $X$, then there is a projection $P$ in $X$ with $\mathscr{R}(P)=X_{1}$
Proof:
If $X_{1}$ contains only $\mathbf{0}$, this is trivial: put $P \mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$ for all $\mathbf{x} \in X$.

Assume $\operatorname{dim} X_{1}=k>0$. By Theorem 9.3, $X$ has then a basis $\left\{\mathbf{u}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{u}_{n}\right\}$ such that $\left\{\mathbf{u}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{u}_{k}\right\}$ is a basis of $X_{1}$. Define

$$
P\left(c_{1} \mathbf{u}_{1}+\cdots+c_{n} \mathbf{u}_{n}\right)=c_{1} \mathbf{u}_{1}+\cdots+c_{k} \mathbf{u}_{k}
$$

for arbitrary scalars $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n}$.

Then $P \mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}$ for every $\mathbf{x} \in X_{1}$, and $X_{1}=\mathscr{R}(P)$.

Note that $\left\{\mathbf{u}_{k+1}, \ldots, \mathbf{u}_{n}\right\}$ is a basis of $\mathcal{N}(P)$. Note also that there are infinitely many projections in $X$, with range $X_{1}$, if $0<\operatorname{dim} X_{1}<\operatorname{dim} X$.
